verb.description: Move along a smooth surface while maintaining continuous contact with it.
examples: she slid down the bank into the water

noun.description: A structure with a smooth sloping surface for children to slide down.
An act of moving along a smooth surface while maintaining continuous contact with it.
examples: use an ice ax to halt a slide on ice and snow

noun.description: A decline in value or quality.
examples: the current slide in house prices

noun.description: A part of a machine or musical instrument that slides.
A rectangular piece of glass on which an object is mounted or placed for examination under a microscope.
A sandal or light shoe without a back.

phrases: Papa had let the business slide after Mama's death
I have to find/make friends and maintain relationships, not letting them slide because we won't be here for long.
At times, it might seem easier to just let things slide but, if you make that a pattern, you're denying your own feelings - not a good thing.
Keith, who could get a chimpanzee to hit a flawless shot, noticed I had let my grip slide.
Once they've enjoyed their neighborhoods in this way, it's almost cruel to let things slide back to the way they were.
origin: Old English slīdan (verb); related to sled and sledge. The noun, first in the sense act of sliding, is recorded from the late 16th century.
